definitions.definition: to clean a room, surface, etc. using a broom (= a type of brush on a long handle)

examples.text: to sweep the floor
Chimneys should be swept regularly.
I don't have to sweep and mop every day.
Don't just stand around—grab a broom and sweep up.
The showroom had been emptied and swept clean.

definitions.definition: to remove something from a surface using a brush, your hand, etc.

examples.text: She swept the crumbs into the wastebasket.
He swept the leaves up into a pile.
She swept the clothes onto the floor and invited him to sit down.

definitions.definition: to move or push somebody/something suddenly and with a lot of force

examples.text: The little boat was swept out to sea.
Their tent was swept away in the storm.
She let herself be swept along by the crowd.

definitions.definition: to move suddenly and/or with force over an area or in a particular direction

examples.text: Rain swept in through the broken windows.
A fire swept through the store on Tuesday night.
Strong winds regularly sweep the islands.

definitions.definition: to move quickly and/or smoothly, especially in a way that impresses or is intended to impress other people

examples.text: Without another word she swept out of the room.
Two police motorcycles swept through the village.
A pair of golden eagles swept across the sky.
She swept past the photographers without a glance.
He swept into the lead with an almost perfect performance.

definitions.definition: to move something, especially your hand or arm, quickly and smoothly in a particular direction

examples.text: He rushed to greet her, sweeping his arms wide.
She swept a hand through her hair.
The traveller swept a hand toward the endless expanse of water.
A wave of tiredness swept over her.
Memories came sweeping back.
Rumours of his resignation swept through the company.
the latest craze **sweeping the nation**

definitions.definition: to move over an area, especially in order to look for something

examples.text: His eyes swept around the room.
The car headlights swept across the front of the building.
Searchlights swept the sky.
She swept the crowd with her binoculars.

definitions.definition: to move, or move something, over a surface, touching it lightly

examples.text: Her dress swept the ground as she walked.

definitions.definition: to brush, comb, etc. your hair in a particular direction

examples.text: Her hair was swept back from her face.

definitions.definition: to form a long, smooth curve

examples.text: The hotel gardens sweep down to the beach.

definitions.definition: to win all the games in a series of games against another team or all the parts of a contest

examples.text: The Blue Jays have a chance to sweep the series.
New Jersey swept Detroit last season.

definitions.definition: to win all the prizes, etc. in a competition
to make somebody fall suddenly and deeply in love with you

examples.text: She’s waiting for some hero to come and sweep her off her feet.

definitions.definition: to win an election by a large number of votes; to make somebody win an election with a large number of votes

examples.text: Macron swept to victory in 2017.

definitions.definition: to try to stop people from finding out about something wrong, illegal, embarrassing, etc. that has happened or that you have done

examples.text: An earlier report, implicating the government, had been conveniently swept under the carpet.

wordOrigin: Old English swāpan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to German schweifen ‘sweep in a curve’.
